Award.AwardTitle: Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance (CSSIA)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. The Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance (CSSIA; http://www.cssia.org) was founded in 2003 to expand the pipeline of professionals in the emerging field of cybersecurity. Since then, CSSIA has worked with community colleges, educators at all levels, and business leaders across the nation to identify and address obstacles in building successful cybersecurity certificate and degree programs. The center distributes course content to more than 260 institutions and hosts a national faculty development academy that provides workshops to over 500 cybersecurity educators annually. With continued funding as an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) support center, CSSIA will continue to expand the nation's pool of entry-level Information Assurance/Cyber Defense (IA/CD) professionals and to improve curricula and teaching in the field.

CSSIA was previously funded as an ATE regional center (NSF Awards DUE-0302612 and DUE-0702872) and as an ATE resource center (NSF Award DUE-1002746). As an ATE support center, CSSIA will focus on four activities:
(1) Increasing the number of minority, female, and veteran students pursuing IA/CD training. An outreach team will provide mentoring and will work with the Association of Computer and Information Science/Engineering Departments at Minority Institutions (ADMI), the Society for Advancement of Hispanics/Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS), and Women in CyberSecurity (WiCyS) to prepare minorities, women, and veterans to compete in cyber defense competitions, which serve as recruiting sources for cybersecurity employers.
(2) Providing updated, relevant curricula and faculty development opportunities that meet IA/CD business and industry needs. Certification classes for college faculty and National Faculty Development Academy workshops will keep faculty members current with industry trends, help them earn industry-recognized credentials, and ensure that they are able to prepare students to combat current and future cybersecurity threats.
(3) Updating and widely distributing innovative virtual teaching and learning environments. CSSIA's virtual platform, which has been developed and fine-tuned over past years, provides a safe setting for experiential learning, including IA/CD competitions, simulations, and on-site workforce experiences.
(4) Leveraging CSSIA's social media network, which has over 3,500 subscribers, across other ATE cybersecurity education centers and projects. This network will be utilized to assist with business, industry, and academic needs assessments; to expand the impact of the resources offered by the ATE centers and projects; and to boost attendance at national IA/CD events, including the Community College Cyber Summit (3CS), the High-Impact Technology Exchange Conference (HI-TEC), the Colloquium for Information Systems Security Education (CISSE), and the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CSSIA Final Impact Report

The Center for Systems Security and Information Assurance has impacted the rgional and national cybersecurity technician pipeline over the last 18 years. The center was able to leveraged the CSSIA Virtual Teaching and Learning Environment to host 200 community college and K-12 cybersecurity student skills competitions and events. This impacted thousands of students over the last 16 years. Worked with national and regional organizations serving targeted underrepresented minority students, including ADMI, WASTC, WiCyS and Veterans Crisis Centers. The list below is a sample of the organizations served:

  • Co-Founder of National Cyber League (NCL)
  • CAE in Cybersecurity Community provided dozen of faculty development workshops and shared over 400 lab exercises developed and published by the CSSIA center
  • CyberPatriot Coached Camps for K12 Students
  • Association of Computer and Information Science/Engineering Departments at Minority Institutions (ADMI) Cyber Challenge
  • Chicago State University GenCyber Camp for students and teachers
  • National Cybersecurity Training & Education Center to develop several cybersecurity courses, mentor community college faculty in preparing for CAE designation
  • Cyber Aces Summer Cyber Camp and US Cyber Challenge (CyberQuest)
  • Center for Supply Chain Automation - Contributed to the annual e-book on cybersecurity and IoT security
  • National CyberWatch Center - Partnership to organize and operate the the Community College Cyber Summit
  • Regional K12 faculty teaching cybersecurity programs or programs that feed cybersecurity technician programs. 
  • Local, State and National Collegiate Cyber Defense Competitions (CCDC)
  • Necessary Skills Now Network - Developed six cybersecurity related case studies, instructional materials and workshops to teach critical skills integrated into cybersecurity case studies 
  • BrookDale Community College Emate Project.  Help design and develop over a dozen cybersecurity related interactive actitivities for students

Operated the National Faculty Development Academy which served over 5,200 Community College and High School faculty during an 18-year period including:

  • Offered over 300 faculty development workshops, courses, and seminars
  • Co-Hosted and managed the Community College Cybersecurity Summit (3CS) Workshops Annually
  • Wisconsin Technical College System Summer Faculty Development Institute
  • NIST Conference Faculty Development Workshops for the Last Four years
  • Hi-Tec Annual Conference
  • NIST K-12 Pre-Conference Workshops
  • CAE Faculty Development Events
  • Chicago State Graduate Course in Cyber Intelligence Program
  • WASTC Winter ICT Educators Conference
  • WASTC Summer Institute

Performed annual cybersecurity industry needs assessments and numerous workforce studies to identify emerging trends, technologies, and skills gap in the national cybersecurity workforce. This research and workforce assessment included:

  • Annual Faculty Development Needs Assessment
  • National Center of Academic Excellence Articulation and Transfer Agreement Database
  • Creation and dissemination of a new Cybersecurity Awareness Course
  • Hosted the CSSIA Web/Social Media Hub
  • Published the CAE K-12 CTE Cybersecurity Career Pathways National Study
  • Developed the Dallas County Cybersecurity Workforce Study
  • Hosted the Illinois CTE Cyber Careers Summit
  • St. Petersburg Community College System (Florida) DACUM Study
  • Presented at the US House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology Testimony ?Role of Community Colleges in Addressing the Nationals Cybersecurity Workforce Shortage?
  • Published a Community College Cybersecurity Workforce Study that examined 12 Leading Community College Cybersecurity Programs and Alignment to the NICE Framework
  • CompTIA Partnership to Align with New Certifications (CySA+, PenTest+, CASP+)
  • Dallas Cybersecurity Workforce Study
  • ISC2 Partnership
  • ISACA Instructor Partnership to Develop CISA Instructor Course
  • National Symposium for IoT Security
  • Chicago State University Graduate Course in Cyber Intelligence
  • Cisco Networking Academy Update to Cybersecurity Essentials, CCNA Industrial, and CCNA CyberOps
  • Vendor Partnerships to Update Products and Technologies: Cisco Systems, Palo Alto Networks, VMware, Dell/EMC, Meraki, Microsoft, Red Hat, Cybati, Rockwell Automation, Siemens, Fanuc

The center has also designed, developed, and implemented a sophisticated virtual teaching and learning environment for cybersecurity programs. The environment includes a library of over 400 lab activities and includes an array of products including firewalls, IDS, IPS, VPNs, DB Servers, Access Control Systems, Incident Response systems, logging and auditing and security monitoring systems.
